There are several substrates including pathways whereby pathogens can invade a
host. The principal pathways have different episodic time frames, but soil
contamination has the longest or most persistent potential for harboring a
pathogen. Diseases caused by organisms in humans are known as pathogenic
diseases. Some of the diseases that a pathogen can cause are smallpox,
influenza, mumps, measles, chickenpox, ebola, and rubella.

Not all pathogens are necessarily undesirable to humans. In entomology,
pathogens are one of the "Three P's" (predators, pathogens and parasitoids) that
serve as natural or introduced biological controls to suppress arthropod pest
